definitions: including or containing everything or everyone within a specified scope or range
surrounding or enclosing something on all sides in a complete manner
examples: The course provides an encompassing view of world history
Her encompassing knowledge of art impressed the museum directors
The mountains formed an encompassing barrier around the valley
An encompassing darkness fell over the abandoned town

definitions: having received emotional support that gives confidence, courage, or hope to continue
actively supported or promoted in development, growth, or acceptance of something
examples: The encouraged students performed better on their final exams
She felt encouraged by her mentor's positive feedback
Encouraged behavior tends to be repeated in young children
The encouraged growth of small businesses boosted the economy

definitions: gradually and steadily intruding or trespassing on someone's territory, rights, or personal space
advancing beyond normal or acceptable limits in a way that causes problems
examples: The encroaching weeds threatened to overtake the entire garden
Encroaching development destroyed much of the natural habitat
The encroaching deadline made everyone work through the weekend
His encroaching questions made the interview subject uncomfortable

definitions: covered with a hard outer layer or coating formed by dried or hardened substance
decorated by having precious stones or ornamental materials set into the surface
examples: The encrusted pipes needed professional cleaning to function properly
Barnacles left the boat's hull completely encrusted after months at sea
The encrusted crown sparkled with diamonds and rubies
She wore an encrusted bracelet worth thousands of dollars

definitions: restricted or burdened in movement or action by heavy or awkward loads
subject to legal claims, debts, or other restrictions that limit use or transfer
examples: The encumbered hikers struggled to climb the steep mountain path
She felt encumbered by too many responsibilities at work
The encumbered property couldn't be sold until debts were cleared
His encumbered estate passed to heirs with significant tax obligations

definitions: containing or providing comprehensive and detailed information on many subjects or one subject
relating to or characteristic of an encyclopedia in scope, detail, or presentation style
examples: His encyclopedic knowledge of baseball statistics amazed sports journalists
The professor's encyclopedic memory helped students during exam review
The book takes an encyclopedic approach to medieval history
She compiled an encyclopedic catalog of rare butterfly species

definitions: at serious risk of extinction as a species due to declining population or habitat loss
exposed to serious harm or danger with potential for severe negative consequences
examples: The endangered pandas require constant protection and monitoring programs
Several endangered plant species grow only in this rainforest
The scandal left his political career seriously endangered
Their endangered relationship needed immediate counseling to survive

definitions: causing someone to feel affection, fondness, or warm feelings through charming or lovable qualities
examples: Her endearing smile made everyone feel welcome at the party
The puppy's endearing behavior won over even cat lovers
His endearing habit of bringing coffee showed thoughtful consideration
The child's endearing mispronunciations amused her parents

definitions: brought to a conclusion or termination with no further continuation expected
having a particular type of conclusion or termination as specified
examples: The ended relationship left both parties feeling relieved
All ended contracts must be filed with the legal department
The open-ended discussion allowed for creative solutions
A blunt-ended tool works better for this type of carving

definitions: naturally occurring in and restricted to a particular geographical region or environment
regularly found among particular people or in a certain area as a persistent problem
examples: Endemic species often face threats when new organisms are introduced
The island's endemic birds evolved unique characteristics over millennia
Corruption became endemic in the organization without proper oversight
Endemic poverty in the region requires comprehensive policy solutions

definitions: relating to glands that secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream to regulate body functions
examples: The endocrine system controls growth and metabolism through hormones
Endocrine disorders can affect mood and energy levels significantly
She specialized in endocrine medicine at the teaching hospital
Regular endocrine testing helps monitor thyroid function

definitions: originating or produced from within an organism, system, or process rather than external sources
examples: Endogenous proteins are synthesized naturally by the body's cells
The plant's endogenous rhythms control flowering regardless of temperature
Economic growth driven by endogenous factors proves more sustainable
Endogenous depression arises from internal chemical imbalances

definitions: naturally provided with a particular quality, ability, or positive attribute
provided with a permanent fund or source of income, especially for an institution
examples: She was endowed with exceptional musical talent from birth
The endowed professor possessed both brilliance and humility
The endowed scholarship helps deserving students attend university
An endowed chair position attracts top researchers to the department

definitions: continuing or lasting for a long time, especially despite difficulties or challenges
bearing or tolerating something difficult or unpleasant with patience and fortitude
examples: Their enduring friendship survived decades of separation and change
The artist created enduring works that still inspire people today
She showed enduring patience with her difficult students
Enduring harsh winters requires both preparation and mental strength

definitions: showing or involving great activity, vitality, or force in movement, expression, or effort
examples: The energetic instructor motivated everyone to complete the workout
Energetic children need plenty of outdoor playtime every day
Her energetic presentation captivated the entire conference audience
The band's energetic performance got everyone dancing

definitions: capable of being enforced or compelled, especially through legal means or formal authority
examples: The contract contains several enforceable clauses protecting both parties
Only enforceable regulations can effectively change corporate behavior
Make sure all agreements are legally enforceable before signing
Enforceable standards ensure consistent quality across the industry

definitions: compelled to be obeyed or observed through the use of authority or power
made stronger or more substantial through additional support or reinforcement
examples: Strictly enforced speed limits reduced accidents on the highway
The enforced curfew kept teenagers safe during civil unrest
The enforced concrete beams could support much heavier loads
Steel rods enforced the bridge structure against earthquake damage

definitions: given the right to vote in political elections, especially after being previously denied
set free from legal, social, or political restrictions and given power or privileges
examples: Newly enfranchised citizens eagerly participated in their first election
The enfranchised women fought to protect their hard-won voting rights
The enfranchised workers gained collective bargaining power through unionization
Technology has enfranchised individuals to start businesses from home

definitions: actively occupied or involved in an activity with attention and interest
having formally agreed to marry someone with a binding commitment
mechanically interlocked or meshed together, as gears or machine parts
examples: The engaged students asked thoughtful questions during the lecture
She remained engaged in community service throughout her career
The engaged couple planned their wedding for next spring
They became engaged after dating for three years
Keep hands clear when gears are engaged in machinery
The engaged clutch transfers power from engine to wheels

definitions: charming and attractive in a way that holds attention and interest
becoming involved or participating actively in an activity or interaction
examples: His engaging personality made him popular at social gatherings
The teacher used engaging activities to help students learn
She spent the afternoon engaging with local community members
Engaging customers through social media increased brand loyalty

definitions: cut, carved, or etched into a hard surface to form letters, designs, or patterns
deeply impressed or permanently fixed in memory, mind, or emotions
examples: The engraved invitation featured elegant gold lettering on ivory paper
Ancient engraved stones tell stories of forgotten civilizations
The tragic event remained engraved in survivors' memories forever
Her kind words were engraved upon his grateful heart

definitions: having all attention or interest completely absorbed or occupied by something
examples: She was so engrossed in the novel that she missed her stop
The engrossed researcher worked through lunch without noticing
Children sat engrossed as the storyteller wove magical tales
He became engrossed in learning everything about astronomy

definitions: capable of absorbing all of someone's attention or interest due to being extremely interesting
examples: The engrossing documentary kept viewers glued to their screens
She writes engrossing mysteries that readers finish in one sitting
His engrossing lecture style made complex topics seem fascinating
The engrossing gameplay made hours pass like minutes

definitions: improved in quality, value, or effectiveness through additions, modifications, or refinements
examples: The enhanced security system includes motion sensors and cameras
Enhanced images revealed details invisible to the naked eye
Students showed enhanced performance after the tutoring program
The enhanced formula provides better protection against stains

definitions: difficult to interpret or understand due to being mysterious, puzzling, or ambiguous in nature
examples: Her enigmatic smile left everyone wondering what she was thinking
The artist's enigmatic paintings invite multiple interpretations
He maintained an enigmatic silence when questioned about his past
Ancient symbols present enigmatic clues to lost civilizations

definitions: giving pleasure, satisfaction, or delight through being pleasant or fun to experience
examples: The enjoyable concert left the audience wanting an encore
Reading became more enjoyable once she found her favorite genre
They spent an enjoyable afternoon exploring the botanical gardens
Making the class enjoyable helps students retain information better

definitions: made bigger in size, extent, or quantity through growth or expansion
expanded in scope, range, or comprehensiveness beyond original limits
examples: The enlarged photograph revealed previously hidden details
Doctors discovered an enlarged heart during the routine checkup
The enlarged edition includes three new chapters
Their enlarged responsibilities came with a salary increase

definitions: having or showing rational, modern, and well-informed outlook free from prejudice or superstition
having achieved spiritual knowledge or insight, especially in Buddhist or Hindu traditions
examples: The enlightened policy promoted equality and justice for all citizens
Enlightened parents encourage their children to think critically
The enlightened master shared wisdom gained through years of meditation
She felt enlightened after the spiritual retreat experience

definitions: giving someone greater knowledge, understanding, or insight about a subject or situation
examples: The enlightening discussion changed how students viewed history
Reading diverse perspectives provides an enlightening experience
Her enlightening presentation clarified many common misconceptions
Travel can be enlightening when approached with open mind

definitions: made more lively, cheerful, or interesting through added energy, spirit, or variety
examples: Music enlivened the otherwise dull corporate event significantly
Her enlivened expression showed genuine excitement about the project
Fresh colors enlivened the previously dreary office space
The enlivened debate brought important issues to light

definitions: filled with extreme anger or fury to the point of losing rational control
examples: The enraged customer demanded to speak with the manager immediately
Enraged protesters stormed the government building demanding justice
She became enraged when she discovered the betrayal
The enraged bull charged at anything that moved

definitions: following immediately afterwards as a consequence or result of what came before
examples: The storm and ensuing floods caused millions in damage
His resignation and the ensuing chaos disrupted company operations
The ensuing investigation revealed widespread corruption in the department
In the ensuing years, technology transformed every industry

definitions: twisted together or caught up in a confused, intertwined mass that's difficult to separate
involved in complicated or compromising relationships, situations, or difficulties
examples: The entangled fishing nets took hours to separate properly
Her long hair became entangled in the thorny bushes
He found himself entangled in a web of lies
The company became entangled in lengthy legal disputes

definitions: showing initiative, resourcefulness, and willingness to undertake new ventures, especially in business
examples: The enterprising student started a successful tutoring business
Enterprising individuals often spot opportunities others miss
Her enterprising spirit led her to create innovative solutions
The town attracted enterprising merchants seeking new markets

definitions: provided with amusement, enjoyment, or engaging diversion through performance or activity
gave consideration to an idea, suggestion, or possibility without necessarily accepting it
examples: The entertained children laughed at the clown's silly antics
Guests felt well entertained throughout the evening celebration
She entertained doubts about the project's ultimate success
The board entertained several proposals before making a decision

definitions: providing amusement, enjoyment, or pleasure through being interesting, amusing, or engaging
examples: The entertaining speaker kept the audience laughing throughout her presentation
They found the documentary both entertaining and educational
She has an entertaining way of explaining complex concepts
The book offers entertaining stories from historical events

definitions: completely captivated or charmed by something so fascinating it holds total attention
examples: The audience sat enthralled by the magician's impossible illusions
Children were enthralled by tales of dragons and knights
She was enthralled with the beauty of the sunset
Readers remain enthralled throughout this gripping thriller novel

definitions: capturing and holding complete attention through being extremely interesting or charming
examples: The enthralling performance earned a standing ovation from everyone
His enthralling stories of adventure inspired young explorers
She gave an enthralling account of her Arctic expedition
The museum's enthralling exhibits bring history to life

definitions: showing intense and eager enjoyment, interest, or approval for something or someone
examples: The enthusiastic crowd cheered wildly for their favorite team
Her enthusiastic response to the proposal encouraged further discussion
Enthusiastic volunteers made the charity event incredibly successful
He's enthusiastic about learning new programming languages

definitions: attractive and tempting in a way that makes someone want to have or do something
examples: The enticing aroma of fresh bread filled the bakery
Travel brochures featured enticing images of tropical beaches
The company made an enticing offer she couldn't refuse
Enticing window displays drew customers into the store

definitions: having the right to do or have something through legal or just claim
believing oneself to be inherently deserving of privileges or special treatment without earning them
examples: All citizens are entitled to vote in democratic elections
Employees are entitled to two weeks of paid vacation
His entitled attitude made him unpopular with coworkers
The entitled customer demanded special treatment without justification

definitions: filled with wonder and delight as if under a spell or hypnotic influence
examples: The entranced audience watched the ballet in complete silence
She stood entranced by the northern lights dancing overhead
Children sat entranced as the puppet show unfolded
He was entranced by her beautiful singing voice

definitions: firmly established and difficult to change, especially regarding attitudes, habits, or positions
examples: Entrenched beliefs about education prove difficult to challenge
The company's entrenched culture resisted modernization efforts
Entrenched positions on both sides prevented compromise
Years of practice left her entrenched in bad habits

definitions: characterized by initiative, risk-taking, and innovation in creating and managing business ventures
examples: Her entrepreneurial mindset led to several successful startups
The city fosters entrepreneurial activity through business incubators
Entrepreneurial skills can be developed through practice and mentorship
Universities now offer entrepreneurial programs for aspiring founders

definitions: completely surrounding, covering, or wrapping something in a way that conceals or protects
examples: The enveloping fog made driving extremely dangerous that morning
An enveloping sense of calm washed over the meditation class
Enveloping darkness fell quickly in the deep forest
Her enveloping embrace provided comfort during difficult times

definitions: arousing envy or jealousy in others due to having desirable qualities, possessions, or advantages
examples: She has an enviable collection of rare first edition books
His enviable position allows him to travel the world
The company maintains an enviable reputation for quality
They live an enviable lifestyle in their beach house

definitions: feeling or showing resentful desire for someone else's possessions, qualities, or advantages
examples: She felt envious of her friend's natural athletic ability
Envious neighbors gossiped about their lottery winnings
His envious glances revealed his desire for recognition
Try not to be envious of others' success

definitions: imagined or visualized as a future possibility or goal through mental imagery or planning
examples: The architect envisioned a building that harmonized with nature
She envisioned herself accepting the Nobel Prize someday
The envisioned changes will transform how we work
Their envisioned future included sustainable living practices

definitions: relating to or caused by enzymes, which are proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions
examples: Enzymatic reactions break down food during digestion process
The researcher studied enzymatic activity in cancer cells
Industrial processes often use enzymatic methods for efficiency
Enzymatic cleaners work by breaking down organic stains

definitions: lasting for a very short time before disappearing or being forgotten
examples: The ephemeral beauty of cherry blossoms attracts countless visitors
Social media creates ephemeral trends that quickly fade
Morning dew provides ephemeral decoration on spider webs
Their ephemeral fame disappeared as quickly as it came
